item.title: ten grain porridge soaker
item.description:
Using a soaker—some raw or ground grain mixed in water, soaked for a bit, then added to the dough after the first mix—you can put almost any grain into a sourdough loaf. For this loaf, I used some Bob’s Red Mill 10 grain hot cereal (good cereal, by the way):

whole wheat, rye, triticale, millet, oats, brown rice, barley, corn, soy beans, oat bran and flaxseeds

I’ve made a few loaves using this technique. More often than not, they’ve ended up with very high hydration (this one pencils out to something like 120% water, which was too much) but a chewy and highly gelatinized crumb. They make great toast.

soaker
  • 300g water, boiling hot
  • 200g ten-grain hot cereal, (Bob's Red Mill)
dough
  • 100g barm, fed 1.5 days in fridge
  • 300g flour, (King Arthur All Purpose White)
  • 300g water, water
  • 10g salt,

Began bulk fermentation at 90F째; after 8 hours the dough was soupy. It might have held its form better a few hours earlier.

I quickly formed the dough on a thick layer of flour and proofed 30 minutes in a banneton

Scooping the loaf into a cast iron dutch oven, I sprinkled on some cornmeal and roughly slashed the top. It baked for 20 minutes with the lid on at 500째F, and 30 (!) minutes with the lid off at 450째F. Out of the oven, the loaf registered 205째F in the center.
